title: Reverse a String Without Library Functions
description: Write a C program to reverse a string without using any string library functions like strrev().
hints: Use two pointers approach - one at start, one at end
Swap characters and move pointers towards center

title: Factorial Using Recursion and Iteration
description: Implement two functions to calculate factorial: one using recursion and another using iteration. Compare their performance.
hints: Recursive: factorial(n) = n * factorial(n-1), base case: factorial(0) = 1
Iterative: Use a loop to multiply numbers from 1 to n
spaceComplexity: O(n) for recursion, O(1) for iteration

title: Implement strcpy Function
description: Implement your own version of the strcpy() function that copies a string from source to destination.
hints: Use pointers to traverse both strings
Copy character by character until null terminator
Don't forget to add null terminator at the end

title: Implement strcat Function
description: Implement your own version of the strcat() function that concatenates two strings.
hints: First, find the end of destination string
Then copy source string from that position
Ensure null terminator is placed correctly

title: Pointer to Pointer (Double Pointer)
description: Write a program demonstrating pointer to pointer concept. Swap two numbers using double pointers.
hints: Double pointer points to address of another pointer
Use **ptr to access the actual value
Remember: ptr -> *ptr -> **ptr

title: Structure vs Union Differences
description: Create a program to demonstrate the key differences between structures and unions, especially memory allocation.
hints: Structure allocates separate memory for each member
Union allocates shared memory (size of largest member)
Print sizeof() for both to see the difference

title: File Read and Write Operations
description: Write a program to read data from a file, process it (e.g., count words, lines), and write results to another file.
hints: Use fopen() to open files with appropriate modes
Use fgets() or fscanf() to read data
Use fprintf() or fputs() to write data
Always close files with fclose()

title: Dynamic Memory Allocation (malloc, calloc, realloc)
description: Demonstrate the differences between malloc, calloc, and realloc. Create a dynamic array that grows as needed.
hints: malloc allocates uninitialized memory
calloc allocates and initializes memory to zero
realloc resizes previously allocated memory
Always check if allocation succeeded (NULL check)

title: Function Pointers Implementation
description: Create a calculator program using function pointers. Implement add, subtract, multiply, divide operations.
hints: Declare function pointer with matching signature
Store addresses of functions in pointer
Call functions through pointer dereference

title: Find Second Largest Element in Array
description: Write a C program to find the second largest element in an array without sorting.
hints: Track both largest and second largest in single pass
Update both when needed
Handle edge cases (all elements same, less than 2 elements)

title: Check if String is Palindrome
description: Write a function to check if a given string is a palindrome, ignoring spaces and case.
hints: Use two pointers from start and end
Skip non-alphanumeric characters
Convert to same case for comparison

title: Matrix Transpose
description: Write a program to find the transpose of a matrix. Handle both square and rectangular matrices.
hints: Transpose means rows become columns
For m×n matrix, transpose is n×m
Element at [i][j] goes to [j][i]

title: Linked List Implementation
description: Implement a singly linked list with operations: insert, delete, search, and display.
hints: Define node structure with data and next pointer
Maintain head pointer to track start of list
Update pointers carefully during insert/delete

title: Bitwise Operations - Count Set Bits
description: Write a program to count the number of set bits (1s) in the binary representation of a number.
hints: Use n & (n-1) to remove rightmost set bit
Count how many times this can be done
Alternative: Check each bit using right shift

title: Swap Two Numbers Without Temp Variable
description: Implement three different methods to swap two numbers without using a temporary variable.
hints: Method 1: Using addition and subtraction
Method 2: Using multiplication and division
Method 3: Using XOR bitwise operation

title: Find Prime Numbers Using Sieve of Eratosthenes
description: Implement the Sieve of Eratosthenes algorithm to find all prime numbers up to n.
hints: Create boolean array for numbers 0 to n
Mark multiples of each prime as composite
Start with 2 and mark 4, 6, 8, ... as non-prime

title: Variable Scope and Storage Classes
description: Demonstrate the differences between auto, static, extern, and register storage classes with examples.
hints: auto: default, local scope, automatic allocation
static: retains value between function calls
extern: declares variable defined elsewhere
register: suggests CPU register storage

title: Command Line Arguments Processing
description: Write a program that processes command line arguments (argc, argv) and performs operations based on them.
hints: argc contains count of arguments (including program name)
argv is array of strings containing arguments
argv[0] is program name, argv[1] is first argument

title: String Tokenization (strtok implementation)
description: Implement your own version of strtok() function to split a string based on delimiters.
hints: Use static variable to remember position
Replace delimiter with null terminator
Return pointer to start of each token

title: Binary File Operations
description: Create a program to write and read structures to/from binary files. Implement a simple student database.
hints: Use 'rb' and 'wb' modes for binary files
Use fread() and fwrite() for binary I/O
Write entire structure at once
Be careful with padding in structures

title: Macro vs Function
description: Create examples demonstrating the differences between macros and functions, including side effects and type safety.
hints: Macros: preprocessor replacement, no type checking
Functions: type-safe, have overhead of call
Show side effects with increment in macro

title: Memory Layout of C Program
description: Write a program to demonstrate different memory segments: Text, Data, BSS, Heap, and Stack.
hints: Text: code/instructions
Data: initialized global/static variables
BSS: uninitialized global/static variables
Heap: dynamic allocation (malloc)
Stack: local variables, function calls
